content.content: Medium – 25 Jan 19   A Post Mortem Report: The Constantinople Ethereum Hard Fork Postponement Motivation Reading time: 14 min read       Bringing in this article so that we can have a discussion around it that isn’t trapped on Twitter or Medium.
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses the postponement of the Constantinople Ethereum Hard Fork and provides a post mortem report on the event. The author explains the proposal and invites discussion on the topic. The post also welcomes constructive criticism, questions, and reviews of the proposal.

content.content: One of the things I noticed was that 1052 and 1014 never went past Draft (so didn’t go through Last Call), and a bunch of us (me, @axic, @5chdn) were pointing this out and at least trying to get them set as Final / Accepted in the weeks leading up to the scheduled hard fork date. This isn’t related to any of the issues around postponing the fork or the 1283 EIP (which did follow process), but it is an example of how we should track these sorts of things and actually follow process. It seemed hard to get the attention of EIP editors (no reviews, no comments) on what was a basic administrative clean up (setting status on EIPs that were scheduled to be included). There are two “tracking” issues in the EIP repo around this with more discussion, filed by @fulldecent.   github.com/ethereum/EIPs      Issue: EIP-1052 failed to go through the workflow  	 	opened by fulldecent 	on 2019-01-15 	 	 	  EIP-1052 is currently listed as draft status, however according to announcement from @Souptacular at https://blog.ethereum.org/2019/01/11/ethereum-constantinople-upgrade-announcement/ the latest EF version of clients...          github.com/ethereum/EIPs      Issue: EIP-1014 failed to go through the workflow  	 	opened by fulldecent 	on 2019-01-15 	 	 	  EIP-1014 is currently listed as draft status, however according to announcement from @Souptacular at https://blog.ethereum.org/2019/01/11/ethereum-constantinople-upgrade-announcement/ the latest EF version of clients...        Do we need more EIP editors to help with these admin tasks? How can we help?

content.content: Some of the big takeaways are about overall process improvement, and failure to adhere to the listing process. I drafted a process improvement based on some FEM threads in this PR:   github.com/ethereum/EIPs       Add Stakeholder Review process to EIPs prior to Last Call     by fubuloubu   on 12:18AM - 26 Jan 19 UTC   2 commits   changed 1 files   with 9 additions   and 6 deletions.        Some more links about EIP process improvement suggestions:  https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/956 Decentralizing EIP workflow Proposal: Add Ring tags to EIPs; solicit comments from Ring(s) https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/1100 https://github.com/trailofbits/publications/blob/master/reviews/EIP-1283.pdf

content.content: Thank you very much for recognizing this.  I have worked hard on getting the two-week process adopted (this was part of getting ERC-721 approved) and I believe it has benefitted the community for the ERCs process. It certainly makes it easier for me to find which EIPs I want to review! At the time this was really a big change and risked much criticism so again I appreciate your kind words. However this process also applies to consensus-changing EIPs and it was not followed this time. I believe the issue is that the attitude of EF is /much/ too centralized. They prefer to push their own software changes on the world by announcing on their own channels, rather than using a mildly community-based process like the EIP two-week review. (EDIT: Maybe “prefer” was too strong there, maybe not everyone knows about EIP-1 changes yet…)
